name: Tefillin
longDescription: Tefillin (singular: tefilah; Greek-derived: phylacteries) are a set of two small black leather boxes containing handwritten scrolls inscribed with Torah verses. One box is worn on the upper arm (tefillin shel yad), positioned on the bicep facing the heart, while the other is worn on the head (tefillin shel rosh), centered above the hairline between the eyes. Black leather straps (retzuot) secure the boxes in place.
significance: significance. Historical Accounts and Records The Torah's commandments to bind God's words on hand and head appear in passages datable to the second millennium BCE in their original composition, though the specific practice of tefillin as known today developed over subsequent centuries. These verses establish the religious mandate that Jewish tradition interpreted as requiring physical phylacteries. The Dead Sea Scrolls include tefillin fragments dating to the 1st century BCE, providing the earliest physical evidence of the practice. These Qumran tefillin show some variations from later standardized forms, including different arrangements of texts and some additional passages not included in rabbinic tefillin. This evidence demonstrates both the antiquity and the evolution of the practice. The Mishnah (compiled c. 200 CE) contains tractates discussing tefillin requirements in detail. These discussions assume the reader knows what tefillin are and focus on legal particulars: valid and invalid materials, proper construction methods, and rules for wearing. This literature forms the foundation for all subsequent halakhic discussion. The Talmud (completed c. 500 CE) expands Mishnaic discussions with further legal analysis and narrative material. Stories about great sages and their tefillin practices appear alongside technical discussions. One famous passage describes God wearing tefillin containing passages praising Israel, a mystical image of the covenant's reciprocity. Archaeological discoveries across the Jewish world confirm continuous tefillin use throughout antiquity. Fragments have been found in diverse locations, and descriptions appear in Greek and Roman sources where Jewish practices attracted curiosity. The Letter of Aristeas (2nd century BCE) mentions phylacteries in describing Jewish customs. Medieval codes, particularly Maimonides' Mishneh Torah and the Shulchan Aruch, established the forms of tefillin practice followed to this day. Regional variations existed, and some continue in different communities, but the core practice achieved remarkable stability across the Jewish world. Modern Use and Replicas Contemporary observant Jews continue wearing tefillin for weekday morning prayers in all traditional Jewish communities worldwide. The practice remains a marker of Orthodox commitment and is increasingly embraced by non-Orthodox Jews seeking to deepen their prayer practice. Global Jewish communities maintain tefillin traditions spanning hundreds of generations. Tefillin production centers exist in Israel, the United States, and other locations with significant Jewish populations. Master craftsmen (battim machers) create the boxes, while sofrim write the scrolls. Quality tefillin command significant prices due to the labor-intensive hand craftsmanship required; sets range from several hundred to several thousand dollars depending on quality level. Verification of tefillin kashrut (fitness for use) requires periodic inspection by qualified scribes. Computer technology has been applied to checking tefillin scrolls, though human experts remain essential for final determination. Communities maintain standards for tefillin dealers and scribes to ensure buyers receive valid tefillin. Bar mitzvah, when Jewish boys assume adult religious obligations at age 13, typically includes learning to wear tefillin. The young man receives his own tefillin set and begins wearing them for morning prayers. This milestone marks entry into Jewish ritual adulthood and the taking on of commandment observance. Tefillin campaigns, particularly those organized by Chabad-Lubavitch, offer Jews opportunities to put on tefillin in public settings. Volunteers set up on street corners, in airports, and at public events, inviting passing Jews to participate. These campaigns have brought tefillin experience to thousands who might not otherwise encounter the practice. Museums and educational institutions display historical tefillin as artifacts of Jewish material culture. These exhibits place tefillin within broader contexts of Jewish history, persecution, and survival. Some museums hold tefillin recovered from Holocaust victims, bearing witness to destroyed communities and preserved traditions. Related Objects and Practices The mezuzah shares tefillin's character as a container for Torah scrolls, though mounted on doorways rather than worn on the body. Together, tefillin and mezuzah ensure that Torah passages surround Jewish life: at the entrance to home and on the person in prayer. Both require handwritten scrolls crafted by qualified scribes. The tallit (prayer shawl) is typically worn together with tefillin during morning prayers. The tallit's fringes (tzitzit) represent another biblical commandment to bind reminders of God's commandments to the body. These garments together create the distinctive appearance of traditional Jewish morning worship. The shofar shares tefillin's character as a ritual object with biblical origin, though serving different functions. Where tefillin mark daily devotion, the shofar sounds on the High Holy Days. Both objects connect contemporary practice to ancient biblical commands and patriarchal traditions. The Torah scroll itself represents the source of tefillin texts and the broader tradition of written Scripture in Judaism. Tefillin might be understood as portable Torah, bringing the sacred text into direct contact with the body. The same standards of scribal care apply to both Torah scrolls and tefillin scrolls. Kabbalistic amulets sometimes drew on tefillin imagery and associated sacred names. While amulets remain controversial in Judaism, the impulse to bind divine names to the body for protection shares something with tefillin's logic, though tefillin themselves are commandments rather than magical objects. Christian phylacteries, referenced in Matthew 23:5, demonstrate awareness of Jewish tefillin practice in the New Testament period. This passage's critique of ostentatious phylactery-wearing confirms that the practice was visible and significant in Second Temple Judaism, even as Christianity would develop differently. Bibliography Primary Sources Torah : Exodus 13:1-16, Deuteronomy 6:4-9, 11:13-21 Mishnah , Tractates Berakhot, Shabbat, Eruvin, Megillah, Menachot Babylonian Talmud , Tractates Berakhot, Menachot, Sanhedrin Maimonides. Mishneh Torah , Hilkhot Tefillin. Various translations Secondary Sources Cohn, Abraham. An Introduction to Jewish Prayer . Philadelphia: Jewish Publication Society, 2000 Donin, Hayim Halevy.
